Definition.WordDefinition: COWARD, n. One who in a perilous emergency thinks with his legs.
Coward, SC (town, FIPS 17215) Location: 33.97215 N, 79.74830 W Population (1990): 532 (211 housing units) Area: 8.9 sq km (land), 0.0 sq km (water) Zip code(s): 29530

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Coward \Cow"ard\, n. A person who lacks courage; a timid or pusillanimous person; a poltroon. [1913 Webster]
A fool is nauseous, but a coward worse. --Dryden.
Syn: Craven; poltroon; dastard. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Coward \Cow"ard\ (kou"?rd), a. [OF. couard, coard, coart, n. and adj., F. couard, fr. OF. coe, coue, tail, F. queue (fr. L. coda, a form of cauda tail) + -ard; orig., short-tailed, as an epithet of the hare, or perh., turning tail, like a scared dog. Cf. {Cue}, {Queue}, {Caudal}.] 1. (Her.) Borne in the escutcheon with his tail doubled between his legs; -- said of a lion. [1913 Webster]
2. Destitute of courage; timid; cowardly. [1913 Webster]
Fie, coward woman, and soft-hearted wretch. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
3. Belonging to a coward; proceeding from, or expressive of, base fear or timidity. [1913 Webster]
He raised the house with loud and coward cries. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
Invading fears repel my coward joy. --Proir. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Coward \Cow"ard\, v. t. To make timorous; to frighten. [Obs.] [1913 Webster]
That which cowardeth a man's heart. --Foxe. [1913 Webster]
coward n 1: a person who shows fear or timidity 2: English dramatist and actor and composer noted for his witty and sophisticated comedies (1899-1973) [syn: {Noel Coward}, {Sir Noel Pierce Coward}]
